pullRequest.body:
Define tight measures (by first defining separable and pre-tight measures).

Define some api for all three concepts

Prove Ulam's tightness theorem and a strengthened version of this. 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
OLD COMMENT, which has been resolved:

I’m struggling to prove `of_isSeparable_on_metric`, which should easily follow from the definition of IsSeparable and the result above it by passing to sub spaces and back, but it does not …
Posted on Zulip: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113489-new-members/topic/Subspaces.2C.20topological.20and.20measurable.20properties/near/436666189.
The linter is not happy...

> The linter is not happy...

Thanks, I fixed it now! I forgot to run `#lint` again after incorporating the points from the previous review.

[#12519](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12519) also defines a notion of separability of measures, `SeparableMeasureSpace`. I believe that my definition should agree with that definition on suitable spaces, but that the definition therein is probably the more general. As I'm defining very little API for `IsSeparable` in my file, I do not think this will bite the reviewing process: once we establish that the definition in #12519 generalizes `IsSeparable`, we can rewrite my special case as a lemma and adapt the other results by a simple `rw`.

### PR summary [222d066fa9](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12394/commits/222d066fa9985b2342ef1f9a676762234dfa9066)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Measure.Tight` (new file)|1416|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IsPretight`
`+ IsPretight.of_isTight`
`+ IsTight`
`+ add`
`+ const_mul`
`+ exists_countable_isSigmaCompact_cover`
`+ exists_countable_totallyBounded_union`
`+ exists_denseRange_sub_le_measure_univ_of_separableSpace`
`+ exists_denseRange_sub_le_measure_univ_of_separableSpace_compl`
`+ exists_isCompact_nat`
`+ exists_sub_le_measure_accumulate`
`+ exists_sub_le_measure_accumulate2`
`+ exists_sub_le_measure_accumulate_compl`
`+ exists_totallyBounded_nat`
`+ iff_countable_isSigmaCompact_cover`
`+ iff_exists_isCompact_measure_compl_le`
`+ iff_isCompact_nat`
`+ instance [TopologicalSpace α] [T2Space α] [OpensMeasurableSpace α] [hk: IsFiniteMeasureOnCompacts μ]`
`+ isPretight_iff_completeSpace`
`+ of_compactSpace`
`+ of_countable_isSigmaCompact_cover`
`+ of_innerRegular`
`+ of_isCompact_nat`
`+ of_isPretight_completeSpace`
`+ of_isSeparableSpace_completeSpace`
`+ of_isSeparablySupported_completeSpace`
`+ of_isSeparablySupported_on_countablyGenerated_uniformSpace`
`+ of_le_isTight`
`+ of_restrict_isTight`
`+ of_separableSpace`
`+ of_separableSpace_on_countablyGenerated_uniformSpace`
`+ of_totallyBounded`
`+ of_totallyBounded_nat`
`+ separablySupported_nat_iff`
`+ to_isSeparablySupported_on_countably_generated_uniformSpace`
`+ totallyBounded_nat_iff`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
This looks great! Minor nitpick: if lemmas mention compact sets, can you use `isCompact` in the lemma name instead of just `compact`, to make search easier?
I feel like some statements should be written in a different way, see below.

**[imports]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion import Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Measure.TightOld import Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Measure.Stieltjes ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion apply forall₂_congr; rintro ε -; constructor ```

**[imports]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion import Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Measure.TightOld import Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Measure.Tilted ```

```suggestion
lemma exists_totallyBounded_nat [UniformSpace α] (h : IsPretight μ) :
```
It is better to try to use the same names as in the statement. If the statements mentions that something exists, use `exists` instead of `has`. If the statement mentions `TotallyBounded`, use `totallyBounded` (no underscores).

```suggestion
    ∀ ε > 0, ∃ n, μ Set.univ - ε ≤ μ (Set.Accumulate K n) := by
```
Please use only inequalities signs "less than" or "less than or equal to", for coherence everywhere in the library (except in quantifiers like your `∀ ε > 0`, where it's not possible to swap directions).
For now, the full definition is `MeasureTheory.IsSeparable`. It should be instead `MeasureTheory.Measure.IsSeparable`, to make sure that you can write it as `μ.IsSeparable` with dot notation.
This name does not really correspond to the statement. `iff_exists_isCompact_measure_compl_le`? (This is maybe too long, but much easier to find).
move `n` left of the colon.
the lemma name is not right any more (and I'm asking you again to change it below :-).
move epsilon and the positivity assumption left of the colon.

This lemma shouldn't be private, as it could very well be useful in another context. Its name should rather be something like `exists_sub_le_measure_accumulate`, to follow more closely the symbols in the statement and make it more easily findable (your name mentions `almost`, `cover`, `approx` but none of these could be guessed by an educated reader).

Could you please review the other lemma names below with the same state of mind?

Do you feel the same about the other lemmas I had made private before? I've removed `private` from them for now, although I'm not entirely sure what the nicest place for them would be. Should I run `find_home` on them, or should I keep them here, close to where they are actually used?
The relevant property here is no that the `K n` are closed, but that they are measurable. Could you switch the lemma to this assumption?
Above in the file, `K` was a set, or a sequence of sets. Here it's a sequence of points, which can be confusing. Could you use maybe `u` for sequences of points, all over the file?

```suggestion
    ∀ ε > 0, ∀ δ > 0, ∃ N : ℕ, μ (Set.univ) - ε ≤ μ (⋃ i ≤ N, Metric.ball (K i) δ) := by
```
You are going to have a standing assumption `UniformSpace α` in a lot of lemmas below. It's probably worth putting it on a `variable` line (opening a section to contain its scope if necessary).
move `n` left of the colon.
Why are you naming the `i` instance? If you don't need a name for instances, don't provide one. Same thing below.

Tell me if I am wrong, but I feel like the condition should rather be
```math
\mu(S^c) = 0.
```
This is equivalent for finite measures but it seems more natural to me.
This condition appears at many places in the file.
You are right, I've changed this (and it cleans up some proofs as well!)

When dealing with separablility, you assume that the uniformity filter is countably generated, and in that case separable is equivalent to secound-countable (see [UniformSpace.secondCountable_of_separable](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/UniformSpace/Cauchy.html#UniformSpace.secondCountable_of_separable)). This makes me think that the right notion is maybe secound-countable? Again tell me if I am wrong.

I'm not restricting to countably generated uniformity filters in general, but I think this condition is needed to get the implication pretight -> separable. I think that the key ingredient of IsSeparable is that you get a separable support, so I would prefer to use this definition. We could also introduce some IsSecondCountablySupported definition, but I don't think that will have a lot of usage (I've never seen this at least).

Well it seems to me that whenever you deal with separability in theorems, you either assume that the uniformity filter is countably generated or the space is pseudo metric, so in each case second-countable does not lose generality. But if you are convinced that separability adds something, feel free to resolve conversation.

I agree that second-countable does not lose generality. What I meant is that the definition in the literature seems to be in terms of separable support, rather than in terms of second-countable support, so I'm not sure if using a different definition is efficient here?
I see. I do not have the answer, so maybe it's simpler if you leave it as it is.

```suggestion
  refine ⟨Set.univ, TopologicalSpace.isSeparable_univ_iff.mpr ‹_›, ?_⟩
  rw [Set.compl_univ, measure_empty]
```

Instead of writing this as "there exists some `n` such that", better spell it as "for all large enough `n`, then ..." (written in Lean as ∀ᶠ n in atTop, ...). When you need to access such an `n`, use `(exists_sub_le_measure_accumulate ...).exists`. Same thing in the next two lemmas.
The inequality is still in the wrong direction in `hε`.

This formulation is really strange: what the lemma seems to be saying is: I can construct a clever sequence `u` with a dense range such that for all positive epsilon, ...
But what is true is rather: whatever sequence u with a dense range, then ...
So you should rather start from a sequence with a dense range, and prove your conclusion for it. In the application of the lemma, pick any sequence using separability and apply the lemma to this sequence. In this way, it is clearer that separability and nonemptyness of alpha are not really relevant here. 

Even better, it points you to a better lemma: if `u` is a sequence such that `μ ((closure (range u))ᶜ) = 0`, then the conclusion of your lemma holds, with the same proof. The advantage of this new lemma (that should probably replace the current `exists_denseRange_sub_le_measure_univ_of_separableSpace`) is that you can avoid all discussion of subtypes in the tedious proof of `of_isSeparablySupported_on_countablyGenerated_uniformSpace` below (i.e., don't prove it first assuming the space is separable and then restricting to a subtype, but instead give a direct proof).

pullRequest.title: feat : define pre-tight and tight measures

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(UniformSpace) : TotallyBounded + countably generated -> Separable

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: separable measure and sufficient condition for Lp spaces to be second-countable
Prove CLT assuming Lévy continuity theorem
